          <items id="comment">Utilise the more detailed archetypes to describe structured or more complex anatomical sites, or to support recording the source site at run-time by the application. If the body site has been fully identified in the 'Source site' data element, this SLOT becomes redundant.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0015">
          <items id="text">Collection date/time</items>
          <items id="description">The date and time that collection has been ordered to take place or has taken place.</items>
          <items id="comment">This datetime will be captured primarily in the INSTRUCTION timing, ACTION time or OBSERVATION times. However, as this is a critical piece of information, it can be useful to also associate it directly with the specimen itself.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0027">
          <items id="text">Physical properties</items>
          <items id="description">Physical dimensions, mass or non-measurable properties of the specimen.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example: Volume, mass, circumference, colour, smell, turbidity. This element can be used to specify the properties of the specimen to be collected, in the context of an INSTRUCTION archetype, or the properties of the specimen which was collected, in the context of an ACTION or OBSERVATION archetype. For example, an INSTRUCTION may request the collection of 20 ml of blood, while the corresponding ACTION records that only 15 ml was collected.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0029">
          <items id="text">Specimen type</items>
          <items id="description">The type of specimen.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example: Venous blood, bacterial culture, cytology, or tissue sample. Coding of the specimen type with a terminology is preferred, where possible.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0034">
          <items id="text">Date/time received</items>
          <items id="description">The date and time that the sample was received at the laboratory.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0041">
          <items id="text">Adequacy for testing</items>
          <items id="description">Information about whether the specimen was adequate for testing.</items>
          <items id="comment">This element is intended to be used to record a judgement about whether or not the specimen quality was good enough for testing, and whether or not testing has been carried out. Coding of the specimen quality issues with a terminology is preferred, where possible.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0042">
          <items id="text">Specimen quality issue</items>
          <items id="description">A specific quality issue with a specimen.</items>
          <items id="comment">Coding of the specimen quality issues with a terminology is preferred, where possible.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0045">
          <items id="text">Comment</items>
          <items id="description">Additional narrative about the specimen not captured in other fields.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0052">
          <items id="text">Haemolysed</items>
          <items id="description">The specimen was haemolysed.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0053">
          <items id="text">Lipaemic</items>
          <items id="description">The specimen was lipaemic.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0054">
          <items id="text">Incorrect additive</items>
          <items id="description">An incorrect additive such as a transport medium or preservative was added to the specimen.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0055">
          <items id="text">Insufficient amount</items>
          <items id="description">The available amount of specimen was insufficient to undertake the examination.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0062">
          <items id="text">Satisfactory</items>
          <items id="description">The specimen is of sufficient quality to allow reporting.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0063">
          <items id="text">Unsatisfactory - analysed</items>
          <items id="description">The specimen is unsatisfactory but has been analysed.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0064">
          <items id="text">Unsatisfactory - not analysed</items>
          <items id="description">The specimen is unsatisfactory and has not been analysed.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0067">
          <items id="text">Collection setting</items>
          <items id="description">Identification of the physical setting in which the specimen is collected.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example: laboratory outpatient clinic, at home, or hospital ward. This specifies the type of specimen collection location within the healthcare environment. The specimen collection setting may provide additional information relevant to the analysis of the result.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0068">
          <items id="text">Processing details</items>
          <items id="description">Structured details about preparation or processing of the specimen.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example: Staining or fixation.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0070">
          <items id="text">Specimen collector identifier</items>
          <items id="description">Identifier of the person or organisation responsible for collecting the specimen.</items>
          <items id="comment">This element is intended to be used where the specimen has already been collected and the actual collector is known.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0071">
          <items id="text">Specimen collector details</items>
          <items id="description">The person or organisation responsible for collecting the specimen.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0079">
          <items id="text">Collection description</items>
          <items id="description">Narrative description about the collection of the specimen.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0080">
          <items id="text">Number of containers</items>
          <items id="description">The total number of physical units holding this specimen.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example: Number of buckets, jars, vials, tubes, blocks, slides or grids.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0083">
          <items id="text">Additional collection details</items>
          <items id="description">Addtional details related to specific collection methods.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example details about needle biopsies in prostate cancer, where both the request and reporting about the specimen are detailed and specific.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0085">
          <items id="text">Container details</items>
          <items id="description">Details about containers used.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0087">
          <items id="text">Source site</items>
          <items id="description">Identification of the body site or other location from where the specimen is collected.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example: 'wound on left calf', 'IV cannula right arm', 'right kidney'.
Coding of the name of the source site with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Use this data element to record precoordinated source sites. If the requirements for recording the source site are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the 'Structured source site' SLOT in this archetype. If the source site is included in the 'Specimen type' via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0088">
          <items id="text">External identifier</items>
          <items id="description">A unique identifier of the specimen, assigned by a party external to the laboratory.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example: 'Requester ID', 'Archive ID, 'Biobank ID'.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0089">
          <items id="text">Icteric</items>
          <items id="description">The specimen was icteric.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0090">
          <items id="text">Handling error</items>
          <items id="description">An error arose when handling the specimen. For example: Incorrect storage, broken container.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0091">
          <items id="text">Age</items>
          <items id="description">The specimen was too old to analyse or to analyse accurately.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0092">
          <items id="text">Technical failure</items>
          <items id="description">The specimen could not be analysed for technical reasons.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0093">
          <items id="text">Transport details</items>
          <items id="description">Structured details about transport of the specimen.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0094">
          <items id="text">Clotted</items>
          <items id="description">The specimen was clotted.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0095">
          <items id="text">Incorrectly labelled</items>
          <items id="description">The specimen was labelled incorrectly.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0096">
          <items id="text">Digital representation</items>
          <items id="description">Structured details about a digital representation of the specimen.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example the scanned image of a histopathology slide.</items>
        </items>
      </term_definitions>
    </component_ontologies>
    <component_ontologies archetype_id="openEHR-EHR-CLUSTER.anatomical_location.v1">
      <term_definitions language="en">
        <items code="at0083">
          <items id="text">Occurrence</items>
          <items id="description">One or more sides of the body.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0084">
          <items id="text">Unilateral</items>
          <items id="description">One-sided.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0085">
          <items id="text">Bilateral</items>
          <items id="description">Two-sided.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0086">
          <items id="text">Left and right</items>
          <items id="description">Both sides of the body.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0000">
          <items id="text">Anatomical location</items>
          <items id="description">A physical site on or within the human body.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0001">
          <items id="text">Body site name</items>
          <items id="description">Identification of a single physical site either on, or within, the human body.</items>
          <items id="comment">This data element is the only mandated data point in this archetype and should be used as the primary data point to record an anatomical location with a commonly used name. It is strongly recommended that 'Body site name' be recorded as specifically as is anatomically possible. For example: record 'upper eyelid' rather than recording 'eyelid' with 'upper' as a qualifier; 'fifth rib' rather than 'rib' with a numeric qualifier. Use the other data elements for laterality, aspect, region and anatomical line to provide more detail.

This data element should be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible - an appropriate termset for use here could comprise individual concepts or a list of precoordinated terms. Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available.

If body site name is already identified in the parent archetype, then this data element may be redundant. Alternatively, a use case has been identified where the value may be duplicated into this element to support semantic querying using this archetype, rather than the data element within the parent.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0002">
          <items id="text">Laterality</items>
          <items id="description">The side of the body on which the identified body site is located.</items>
          <items id="comment">If the identified body site has no laterality, this data element should not have a value. 
If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include laterality, then this data element is redundant.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0003">
          <items id="text">Left</items>
          <items id="description">Left side of the body.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0004">
          <items id="text">Right</items>
          <items id="description">Right side of the body.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0023">
          <items id="text">Description</items>
          <items id="description">Narrative description that can be used to further refine and support the 'Body site name'.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example: adjacent to the vermilion border; a tattoo covers the bottom half of this area.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0053">
          <items id="text">Alternative structure</items>
          <items id="description">Additional detail about the anatomical site using alternative approaches to describe the same body site.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example, relative location or precise locations using coordinates. </items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0054">
          <items id="text">Multimedia representation</items>
          <items id="description">Image or other media used to support identification of the body site.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0055">
          <items id="text">Anatomical Line</items>
          <items id="description">Additional detail using theoretical lines drawn through anatomical structures used to provide a consistent reference point on the human body.</items>
          <items id="comment">Common anatomical lines have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. The additional use of this data element allows for recording of the typical position of the heart's apex beat at 5th intercostal space, left side, and mid-clavicular line. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include anatomical line, then this data element is redundant.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0056">
          <items id="text">Midaxillary line</items>
          <items id="description">Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the apex of the axilla.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0057">
          <items id="text">Anterior axillary line</items>
          <items id="description">Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the anterior axillary skinfold.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0058">
          <items id="text">Posterior axillary line</items>
          <items id="description">Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the posterior axillary skinfold.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0059">
          <items id="text">Mid-clavicular line</items>
          <items id="description">Line running vertically down the surface of the body, parallel to the midline and passing through the midpoint of the clavicle.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0060">
          <items id="text">Mid-pupillary line</items>
          <items id="description">Line running vertically down the face through the midpoint of the pupil when looking directly forward.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0062">
          <items id="text">Midline</items>
          <items id="description">Line running vertically which divides the body into left and right portions, passing through the head, spinal cord, and umbilicus. Alternatively it can refer to a line dividing a body part into two equal portions, for example a digit.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0063">
          <items id="text">Mid-scapular line</items>
          <items id="description">Line running vertically down the posterior surface of the body, parallel to the midline and passing through the inferior point of the scapula.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0064">
          <items id="text">Aspect</items>
          <items id="description">Qualifying detail about the specific aspect of the identified body site.</items>
          <items id="comment">Use to increase precision of identification of the body site, if required. Common aspects have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. Assumes that the body is being described while in the anatomical position. For example: proximal urethra; plantar aspect of the left thumb. Multiple aspects can also be described, if required, by allowing for 0..2 occurrences. For example: a lesion may be on the left anterior/lateral (ie anterolateral) chest wall. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include the aspect, then this data element is redundant.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0065">
          <items id="text">Specific site</items>
          <items id="description">Additional detail using a specific region or a point on, or within, the identified body site.</items>
          <items id="comment">Use to increase precision of identification of the body site, if required. For example, the upper right quadrant or McBurney's point on the abdominal wall or interphalangeal joint of the great toe. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include the specific site, then this data element is redundant.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0067">
          <items id="text">Medial</items>
          <items id="description">Towards the midline of the body site.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0068">
          <items id="text">Lateral</items>
          <items id="description">Towards the side, or edge, of the body site.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0069">
          <items id="text">Superior</items>
          <items id="description">Above the body site, often meaning towards the head.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0070">
          <items id="text">Inferior</items>
          <items id="description">Below the body site, often meaning towards the feet.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0071">
          <items id="text">Anterior</items>
          <items id="description">Towards the front, or ventral surface, of  the body site.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0072">
          <items id="text">Posterior</items>
          <items id="description">Towards the back, or dorsal surface, of the body site.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0073">
          <items id="text">Proximal</items>
          <items id="description">More central or closer to the point of attachment, and usually describing part of a limb, digit or appendage.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0074">
          <items id="text">Distal</items>
          <items id="description">More peripheral, or further from the point of attachment, and usually describing part of a limb, digit or appendage.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0075">
          <items id="text">Palmar</items>
          <items id="description">Towards the palm of the hand.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0076">
          <items id="text">Plantar</items>
          <items id="description">Towards the sole of the foot.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0077">
          <items id="text">Mid</items>
          <items id="description">In the middle of the body site.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0078">
          <items id="text">Oral</items>
          <items id="description">Towards the mouth. Usually used to describe locations within the digestive system.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0079">
          <items id="text">Anal</items>
          <items id="description">Towards the anus. Usually used to describe locations within the digestive system.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0080">
          <items id="text">Deep</items>
          <items id="description">Away from the surface of the body site.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0081">
          <items id="text">Superficial</items>
          <items id="description">Towards the surface of the body site.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0082">
          <items id="text">Dorsal</items>
          <items id="description">Towards the back of the hand or top of the foot. To be used as opposites of palmar or plantar, not as a synonym of posterior.</items>
        </items>
      </term_definitions>
    </component_ontologies>
    <component_ontologies archetype_id="openEHR-EHR-CLUSTER.laboratory_test_panel.v0">
      <term_definitions language="en">
        <items code="at0000">
          <items id="text">Kultur</items>
          <items id="description">Laboratory test result as a panel/battery/profile structure common to clinical pathology testing.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0013">
          <items id="text">Panel detail</items>
          <items id="description">Further details including the individual analytes, specimen for the panel or a further nested panel.</items>
        </items>
      </term_definitions>
    </component_ontologies>
    <component_ontologies archetype_id="openEHR-EHR-CLUSTER.laboratory_test_analyte.v1">
      <term_definitions language="en">
        <items code="at0000">
          <items id="text">Pro Erreger</items>
          <items id="description">The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0001">
          <items id="text">Erregername</items>
          <items id="description">The value of the analyte result.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example '7.3 mmol/l', 'Raised'. The 'Any' data type will need to be constrained to an appropriate data type in a specialisation, a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte result. The Quantity data type has reference model attributes that include flags for normal/abnormal, reference ranges and approximations - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_quantity_class for more details.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0003">
          <items id="text">Comment</items>
          <items id="description">Additional narrative about the analyte result, not captured in other fields.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0004">
          <items id="text">Reference range guidance</items>
          <items id="description">Additional advice on the applicability of the reference range to this result or may carry text or coded textual guidance as to whether the result is within the normal range.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example, 'within normal limits for age and sex'.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0005">
          <items id="text">Result status</items>
          <items id="description">The status of the analyte result value.</items>
          <items id="comment">The values have been specifically chosen to match those in the HL7 FHIR Diagnostic report, historically derived from HL7v2 practice. Other local codes/terms can be used via the Text 'choice'.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0006">
          <items id="text">Result status time</items>
          <items id="description">The date and time that the analyte result was issued for the recorded ‘Result status’.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0014">
          <items id="text">Analyte result detail</items>
          <items id="description">Further detail regarding an individual result.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0015">
          <items id="text">Registered</items>
          <items id="description">The existence of the test is registered in the Laboratory Information System, but there is nothing yet available.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0016">
          <items id="text">Partial</items>
          <items id="description">This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) Test Result: data in the Test Result may be incomplete or unverified.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0017">
          <items id="text">Preliminary</items>
          <items id="description">Verified early results are available, but not all results are final. This is a sub-category of 'Partial'.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0018">
          <items id="text">Final</items>
          <items id="description">The Test result is complete and verified by an authorised person.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0019">
          <items id="text">Corrected</items>
          <items id="description">The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0020">
          <items id="text">Amended</items>
          <items id="description">The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist, and result data has been changed.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0021">
          <items id="text">Appended</items>
          <items id="description">Subsequent to being final, the report has been modified by adding new content. The existing content is unchanged. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0022">
          <items id="text">Entered in error</items>
          <items id="description">The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0023">
          <items id="text">Cancelled</items>
          <items id="description">The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed (also sometimes called 'aborted').</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0024">
          <items id="text">Nachweis?</items>
          <items id="description">The name of the analyte result.</items>
          <items id="comment">The value for this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte. For example: 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. Coding with an external terminology is strongly recommended, such as LOINC, NPU, SNOMED CT, or local lab terminologies.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0025">
          <items id="text">Validation time</items>
          <items id="description">The date and time that the analyte result was validated in the laboratory by a healthcare practitioner.</items>
          <items id="comment">In many jurisdictions the 'Result status' is assumed to include medical validation i.e. a 'final' result will be assumed to be medically validated, but in others this will be recorded and reported separately using this data element.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0026">
          <items id="text">Zugehörige Laborprobe</items>
          <items id="description">Identification of the specimen used for the analyte result.</items>
          <items id="comment">In some situations, a single Laboratory test result archetype will contain multiple Specimen archetypes and multiple Analyte result archetypes. In these situations, this 'Specimen' data element is needed to be able to connect the results with the correct specimens.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0027">
          <items id="text">Analyte result sequence</items>
          <items id="description">The intended position of this analyte result within the overall sequence of analyte results.</items>
          <items id="comment">For example: ''1' '2', '3'. Where multiple analyte results are reported, the 'Analyte result sequence' makes the order in which they were reported explicit.</items>
        </items>
      </term_definitions>
    </component_ontologies>
    <component_ontologies archetype_id="openEHR-EHR-CLUSTER.erregerdetails.v1">
      <term_definitions language="en">
        <items code="at0000">
          <items id="text">*Erregerdetails(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Detailierte Angaben zum nachgewiesenen Erreger.(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0003">
          <items id="text">*Häufigkeit(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Semiquantitative Angabe zur Keimzahl.(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0004">
          <items id="text">*+++(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*reichlich(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0005">
          <items id="text">*+(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*spärlich(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0006">
          <items id="text">*++(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*mäßig(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0016">
          <items id="text">*Virulenzfaktor(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Angabe zu untersuchten
Virulenzeigenschaften oder -genen, z. B. PVL bei S. aureus oder EHEC bei E. coli.(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0017">
          <items id="text">*Resistenzmechanismus Bezeichnung(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Bezeichnung des Resistenzmechanismus. (de)</items>
          <items id="comment">*Ein bestes Beispiel wäre, die Untersuchung eines „Staphylococcus aureus“ der hier die Bezeichnung des Keims ist. (de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0018">
          <items id="text">*MRE Klasse(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Angabe zur MRE-Klassifikation des
Erregers, z. B. 3MRGN oder 4MRGN.(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0019">
          <items id="text">*MRSA(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Methicillin-resistenter Staphylococcus aureus (und CA- community-acquired, LA – lifestock acquired, HA – hospital acquired)(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0024">
          <items id="text">*(+)(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*vereinzelt(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0025">
          <items id="text">*++++(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*massenhaft(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0035">
          <items id="text">*Keimzahl(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Quantitative Angabe zur Keimzahl, z.B. bei Urinen(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0047">
          <items id="text">*Keim Subtyp(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Subtyp, welcher zusätzlich zur Speziesidentifzierung zur weiteren Kennzeichnung des Erregers genutzt werden kann, z. B. spa-Typ im Falle von S. aureus oder MLST-Typ.(de)</items>
          <items id="comment">*Bestimmte Keimsubtypen beeinflussen die Wirtsreaktion bzw. Immunantwort. 
Beispielsweise ein Resultat einer spa-Typsierung bei einem S. aureus oder anderen Typsierungen wie MLST. (de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0048">
          <items id="text">*2MRGN(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Multiresistente Gramnegative Bakterien(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0055">
          <items id="text">*VRE(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Vancomycin-resistente Enterokokken(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0056">
          <items id="text">*LVRE(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Linezolid-Vancomycin-resistenter Enterokokken(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0057">
          <items id="text">*Resistenzmechanismus(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Angabe der bei dem Erreger vorliegenden Resistenzmechanismen, z.B. ESBL oder Carbapenemase.(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0059">
          <items id="text">*Weitere Ergänzungen(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Der Cluster dient dazu, weitere Ergänzungen zum Archetyp Erregerdetails aufzunhemen. (de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0062">
          <items id="text">*Kommentar(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Zusätzliche Infomationen zum Erreger. (de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0063">
          <items id="text">*Resistenzmechanismus Spezialisierung(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Weitere Angaben zum Resistenzmechanismus.(de)</items>
          <items id="comment">*Ein bestes Beispiel wäre, die Untersuchung eines „Staphylococcus aureus“ der hier die Bezeichnung des Keims ist. Jedoch möchte man später nochmal die „Toxine“ des „Staphylococcus aureus“ untersuchen. Hier wären die „Toxine“ die Spezialisierung des untersuchten Keims. (de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0064">
          <items id="text">*Antibiogramm(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Benennung des Antibiogramms welcher zur Bestimmung der Empfindlichkeit bzw. Resistenz von mikrobiellen Krankheitserregern gegenüber Antibiotika verwendet wurde.(de)</items>
          <items id="comment">*Weitere Informationen werden in den Archetypen "Laboranalyt-Panel" und "Labortest-Panel" erfasst.(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0065">
          <items id="text">*3MRGN(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Multiresistente Gramnegative Bakterien(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0066">
          <items id="text">*4MRGN(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Multiresistente Gramnegative Bakterien(de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0067">
          <items id="text">*LRE(de)</items>
          <items id="description">*Linezolid-resistente Enterokokken (de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0068">
          <items id="text">*n (de)</items>
          <items id="description">*nicht bestimmbar (de)</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0069">
          <items id="text">*a (de)</items>
          <items id="description">*nach Anreicherung (de)</items>
        </items>
      </term_definitions>
    </component_ontologies>
    <component_ontologies archetype_id="openEHR-EHR-CLUSTER.location.v1">
      <term_definitions language="en">
        <items code="at0000">
          <items id="text">Empfängerstandort</items>
          <items id="description">Location includes both casual locations (a place used for health care without prior designation or authorisation) and dedicated, formally designated locations. The sites can be private, public, mobile or fixed.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0024">
          <items id="text">Campus</items>
          <items id="description">A group of buildings or other locations such as a site or campus. For example: Campus that is outside the facility, but belongs to the hospital, university.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0025">
          <items id="text">Building</items>
          <items id="description">Either building or structure. These can include rooms, corridors, wings, etc.. It may not have walls or a roof, but is considered a defined/allocated space.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0027">
          <items id="text">Ward</items>
          <items id="description">A ward is part of a medical facility that can contain rooms and other types of locations.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0028">
          <items id="text">Level</items>
          <items id="description">A level in a multi-level building/structure.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0029">
          <items id="text">Room</items>
          <items id="description">A location that was declared as a room. Some locations can have the room in the corridor, e.g. ward XYZ corridor 2; where bed space 2 is in the corridor of the respective ward.  </items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0034">
          <items id="text">Bed Location</items>
          <items id="description">Used to document information about the bed space e.g. bed was placed next to the window or next to the door.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0040">
          <items id="text">Location Type</items>
          <items id="description">The person location type is the categorization of the person's location. For example: Clinic, Home.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0046">
          <items id="text">Location description</items>
          <items id="description">The field contains the optional free text description of the location, e.g. thoracic, heart and vascular surgery.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0047">
          <items id="text">Details</items>
          <items id="description">To record further information about the bed or about the address of the location. For this purpose use the archetype CLUSTER.device or CLUSTER.address.</items>
        </items>
        <items code="at0048">
          <items id="text">Standortschlüssel</items>
          <items id="description">Coding of the location, e.g. the department code (e.g. 2000 thoracic surgery).</items>
        </items>
      </term_definitions>
    </component_ontologies>
